Potential well and step potential within the framework of
minimal length quantum mechanics
H. Hassanabadi
1 , S. Zarrinkamar
2 , and E. Maghsoodi
1,a
1 Department of Basic Sciences, Shahrood Branch, Islamic Azad University, Shahrood, Iran
2 Department of Basic Sciences, Garmsar Branch, Islamic Azad University, Garmsar, Iran
Received: 5 August 2013 / Revised: 4 October 2013
Published online: 18 November 2013 – c
Socieà Italiana di Fisica / Springer-Verlag 2013
Abstract. The potential well and the step potential are studied under the modified Schrödinger equation
due to minimal length in an exact analytical manner. The scattering problems as well as the reflection and
transmission parameters are reported.

1 Introduction
The existence of a minimal length (ML), which is of the order of the Planck length l P =
G¯ h/c 3 ≈ 10
−35 m, is
predicted by many of our physical theories including the theory of quantum gravity (QG), string theory, doubly
special relativity, etc. [1]. Such a ML implies the modification of the ordinary Heisenberg uncertainty principle into the
so-called Generalized Uncertainty Principle (GUP) and the Schrödinger equation itself. Consequently, when our basis
is changed, the physical properties of the systems are modified, too. There are some interesting works which discuss
the origin of such an idea, its possible experimental evidences and/or the related mathematical aspects [2–26]. Quite
recently, it was shown that the modified Schrödinger equation (MScE) due to minimal length possesses an interesting
underlying symmetry; the MScE can be brought into the form of an ordinary Schrödinger equation with a new effective
potential [27]. In the present work, we intend to consider two famous problems of physics, i.e. the potential well and
the step potential, which are important from both research and pedagogical points of view.

5 Conclusions
Both the potential well and the step potential are amongst our significant potentials in quantum mechanics. Here, we
considered these cases within the framework of the modified Schrödinger equation and, based on our recent papers,
we transformed the problem into the ordinary case with a new effective potential. To provide a more useful basis from
both pedagogical and research aspects, we reported the transmission and reflection coefficients, as well. To illustrate
the validity of our results, we included some figures which indicate the correctness of the results.
